About
Directions

This simulation shows the constant enthalpy, entropy, temperature, and quality curves on a pressure-volume diagram for water. By default, the plot shows the phase envelope as a thick black line, and the constant temperature and quality curves in red and grey, respectively. Toggle property curves on or off by clicking the appropriate checkbox above the plot. Toggle the grid on and off using the "Show grid" checkbox. The units for each curve are shown in the top-right of the diagram, such that the numbers written over the curves have that unit. For example, a constant entropy curve with a "7.000" label represents an isentrope with a value of 7.000 kJ/(kg °C).

Details

The thick black line on the pressure-volume diagram represents the phase envelope. Inside the phase envelope is the two-phase region where water vapor and liquid are in equilibrium. Outside of the phase envelope, the phase of water may be liquid, vapor, or supercritical fluid depending on the pressure and specific volume. For a constant temperature curve (an isotherm), pressure remains constant inside the phase envelope, resulting in horizontal lines inside the phase envelope. Curves of constant quality, enthalpy, or entropy do not have constant pressure within the two-phase region, although the slope of the curves may change abruptly when entering and exiting the two-phase region due to the large difference in the thermodynamic properties of liquid water and steam. These constant-property curves were compiled using steam tables, which provide thermodynamic properties of water over a large range of pressures and temperatures. Download steam tables as an Excel spreadsheet or in other formats here.

About

This simulation was created in the Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, at University of Colorado Boulder for LearnChemE.com by Neil Hendren under the direction of Professor John L. Falconer. Address any questions or comments to learncheme@gmail.com. All of our simulations are open source, and are available on our LearnChemE Github repository.

Is your screen too small to fit this application? Try zooming-out on the web page (CTRL+"-" and CTRL+"=" on Windows, or ⌘+"-" and ⌘+"=" on Mac), then refreshing the page. This application is not compatible with Internet Explorer or web browsers that do not support WebGL and HTML5. Recommended browsers are the latest versions of: Chrome, Safari, Firefox, Edge, and Opera.
